column1: grieving most over the words he spoke, that they were to see his face no more. Then they escorted him to the ship.|An wa mek dem baal so a kaaz im tel dem se dem naa go si im fies agen. Den dem fala im go a di ship.

When we had withdrawn from them and set sail, we went on a straight course to Cos, the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.|An wen di taim kom wi lef dem an siel go chriet a Kos, an di neks die wi riich a Ruodz an fram de-so wi ed fi Patara.
We found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, went aboard, and set sail.|Wi fain wan ship we a kraas uova go a Foniisiya, so wi go pan it an siel out.

Having come in sight of Cyprus, we passed to the south of it and sailed to Syria, and landed at Tyre, for there the ship’s cargo was to be unloaded.|Wen wi riich we wi kuda si Saipros, an wi paas it pan di lef-an-said, wi siel go a Siriya. Wi tap a Taiya, kaaz di ship did fi lef di sitn dem we it did a kyari de.

When we found the disciples, we remained there seven days. They told Paul through the Spirit not to go up to Jerusalem. |Afta wi fain di biliiva dem, wi tan wid dem fi sevn die. Di Uoli Spirit shuo di biliiva dem wa did a-go riich Paal iina Jeruusilem, so dem beg im uova an uova no fi go op de.

But when our days were over, we parted and traveled on. Everyone, with wives and children, escorted us until we were outside the city. And we knelt on the shore and prayed. |An wen a did taim fi wi lef dem, wi shub out agen. Aal a dem wid dem waif an pikni fala wi outa di siti. Afta wi go dong pan wi nii an prie pan di biich
After bidding farewell to one another, we boarded the ship, and they returned home.|wi tel wan aneda ba-bai. Den wi go bak pan di ship an dem go baka dem yaad.

We finished the voyage from Tyre when we landed at Ptolemais, where we greeted the brothers and stayed with them for one day.|Wi gwaan siel fram Taiya til wi riich a Talomieyis. An afta wi se oudi tu di biliiva dem, wi tan wid dem fi wan die.

The next day we who were Paul’s companions departed, and arrived at Caesarea, and entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him. |Di neks die wi lef an go a Sesuriiya an go tan a Filip yaad. Im a did wan a di man dem we priich di Gud Nyuuz, an wan a di sevn man dem we di biliiva dem iina Jeruusilem did pik fi luk aafa di uman dem uufa ozban did ded.
He had four virgin daughters who prophesied.|Filip did av fuo daata we neva marid, an di fuo a dem a did prafit.
While we stayed there many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea. |Afta wi did de de fi kopl die, wan prafit niem Agabos kom dong fram Judiya.

When he had arrived, he took Paul’s belt and bound his own hands and feet, saying, “The Holy Spirit says, ‘In this manner the Jews at Jerusalem shall bind the man who owns this belt and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’ ”|Im kom op tu wi, tek Paal belt, an tai op im uona an an fut an se, “Di Uoli Spirit se, ‘A siem so di Juu dem iina Jeruusilem a-go tai op di man uu uon da belt ya, an ton im uova tu di piipl dem we a no Juu.’”

When we heard these things, both we and the residents implored him not to go up to Jerusalem.|Wen wi ier dis, wi an di ada biliiva dem fram di ieriya beg Paal uova an uova se, “Du! No go op a Jeruusilem.”

Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be imprisoned, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”|Den Paal ansa wi se, “Wa unu a du, a baal unu a baal an a brok mi aat? Wel, mi redi no onggl fi dem tai mi op bot aal ef a ded mi a-go ded iina Jeruusilem mi redi fi ded fi mi Laad Jiizas Krais.”

When he would not be persuaded, we kept silent and said, “Let the will of the Lord be done.”|Wen wi si se wi kudn get im fi chienj im main an no go, wi gi op an jos se, “Laad, mek we yu waahn fi apm apm!”
After those days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
column2: Afta dat wi get wi sitn dem an shub out go a Jeruusilem.

column1: Some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us and brought with them Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should lodge.|Som a di biliiva dem fram Sesuriiya kom wid wi tu an liid wi go a Nieson ous we wi did fi stie. Nieson did kom fram Saipros an im a did wan biliiva fram wie bak wen.
When we had come to Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.|Wen wi riich a Jeruusilem, di biliiva dem did api fi tek wi iin.
On the next day Paul went with us to James, and all the elders were present. |Di neks die Paal go wid wi fi go taak tu Jiemz, an aal di elda dem fi di choch did de de.

He greeted them and recounted one by one what God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.|Afta Paal go iin an tel dem oudi, im staat tel dem evriting wa Gad did a du siek-a fi im wok mongks di piipl we a no Juu.

When they heard this, they glorified the Lord. Then they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are who believe, and they are all zealous for the law.|Wen dem ier dis, dem priez Gad. Den dem se tu im se, “Breda, yu si di touzn an touzn a Juu iina Jeruusilem we biliiv iina Jiizas, an aal a dem biliiv an fala di Laa dong tu di laas leta.

They have been informed concerning you that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children nor to observe the customs. |Wel, dem ier se yu a tiich aal a di Juu dem we liv mongks di piipl we a no Juu se dem fi ton we fram we Muoziz tiich, no sorkomsaiz dem pikni, ar liv laik ou Juu fi liv.
What then shall be done? The assembly will certainly meet, for they will hear that you have come.|So, wa wi a-go du wen dem ier se yu de ya?
Therefore do what we tell you. We have four men who have taken a vow.|Wel, dis a wa wi waahn yu fi du: wi av fuo man mongks wi we did mek wan pramis tu Gad

Take these men and be purified with them, and pay their expenses so that they may have their heads shaved. Then all will know that what they were told concerning you is nothing, but that you yourself live in observance of the law. |kyari dem wid yu go a Gad ous an pie di moni we dem fi pie fi get bak kliin, an yu wi get kliin tu. Afta dat dem kyan kot aaf dem ier. Da wie de evribadi wi nuo se wa dem se bout yu a no chuu. Dem wi si se yu liv laik ou di Laa se wi fi liv.

As for the Gentiles who believe, we have written and concluded that they should observe no such thing, except that they abstain from food offered to idols, from sexual immorality, from strangled animals, and from blood.”|Bot yu si di piipl we a no Juu we biliiv, wi did rait tu dem bout wa wi did mek op wi main fi du aredi. Wi tel dem se dem no fi nyam miit we piipl did tek bon sakrifais gi faalz gad, ar miit wid blod stil iina it, ar animal we eng, an dem fi kip we fram aal saat a seks sin.”

Then on the next day, Paul took the men and purified himself with them. And he went into the temple, announcing when the days of purification would be complete and an offering would be given for each one of them.|So di neks die, Paal tek di fuo man dem, an im an dem du wa di Laa se fi du fi get kliin iina Gad yai. Den im go a Gad ous an mek di liida dem nuo se im set di taim fi gi op sakrifais fi im an di man dem.

When the seven days were nearly concluded, the Jews from Asia saw him in the temple, stirred up all the people, and laid hands on him|Wen di sevn die dem aalmuos don, di Juu we kom fram Iezha we did si Paal iina di yaad we Gad ous de rail op di kroud an grab aan pan Paal

crying out, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man teaching all men everywhere against the people and the law and this place. He even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”|an staat baal out, “Aal uu a Juu, unu kom elp wi diil wid da man ya! A da man ya a tiich evribadi evriwe fi ton gens wi piipl, wi Laa, an da uoli plies ya! An fi mek it wosa, im aal kyari som Griik piipl go iina di paat a Gad ous we di Laa se onggl Juu fi go, an mek it no uoli no muor.”

For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, whom they supposed Paul had brought into the temple.|Dem se dis kaaz dem did si Chrofimos we kom fram Efisos iina di siti wid Paal bifuo, so dem tek it se Paal did mek im go iina di paat a Gad ous we onggl Juu fi go.

Then the whole city was provoked, and the people ran together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple. And immediately the doors were shut. |Di uol siti did rail op, an aal a di piipl dem rosh Paal. Dem grab im an jrag im outa di yaad we Gad ous de, an shot di duor kwik kwik.

While they were trying to kill him, news came up to the commander of the battalion of soldiers that all Jerusalem was in an uproar. |Wen dem did a chrai fi kil im, sumadi sen go tel di ed fi touzn suoja se a pie chobl a gwaan iina di siti.

He at once took soldiers and centurions, and ran down to them. When they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.|Im tek som suoja an som a dem liida siem taim an ron dong pan di kroud. Wen di kroud si di ed fi touzn suoja an di ada suoja dem wid im, dem tap biit Paal.

Then the commander came and arrested him, and ordered that he be bound with two chains. Then he asked who he was and what he had done. |Den di ed fi touzn suoja kom an ares im an aada di ada suoja dem fi tai im op wid tuu chien. Den im aks a uu da man ya an a wa im du.

Some in the crowd shouted one thing, some another. As he could not learn the truth because of the uproar, he commanded that he be brought into the barracks.|Som a di piipl iina di kroud kaal out wan sitn an som ada piipl kaal out sitn els. Di ed fi touzn suoja kudn get no we wid wa di kroud did a se, so im gi aada fi dem kyari im go iina di suoja kyamp.
When he came onto the stairs, he was carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the people. |Wen dem riich a di step, di suoja dem afi tek op Paal an kyari im kaaz di kroud did a galang bad.
For the mob of people followed, crying out, “Away with him!”|Di kroud a piipl did a fala dem an a baal out, “Mek wi kil im! Gi wi im mek wi kil im!”

As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the commander, “May I speak to you?” He replied, “Do you know how to speak Greek?|Wen dem did out fi kyari Paal iina di suoja kyamp im se tu di ed fi touzn suoja se, “Mi kyan se sopm tu yu?”Di ed fi touzn suoja aks im se, “Yu kyan taak Griik?
Are you not the Egyptian who in past days caused an uproar and led the four thousand men of the Sicarii out into the wilderness?”
column2: So a no yu a di Ijipshan we jos di ada die did kaaz piipl fi fait gens di govament an we did liid di fuo touzn bad man dem go out iina di dezot?”

column1: Paul said, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus of Cilicia, a citizen of no common city. I beg of you, permit me to speak to the people.”|Paal ansa im se, “Mi a wan Juu. Mi baan an gruo iina Taasos wan big impuotant siti iina Silisiya. Mi a beg yu, gi mi a chaans fi taak tu di piipl dem.”

When he had given him permission, Paul stood on the stairs and motioned with his hand to the people. When there was great silence, he addressed them in the Hebrew language, saying,|Wen di ed fi touzn suoja lou im fi taak tu di piipl dem, Paal tan op pan di step an riez im an fi kwaiyat dong di piipl dem. Wen dem get kwaiyat im taak tu dem iina fi dem Juu langwij.
Brothers and fathers, hear my defense which I now make to you.”|“Aal a unu we uolda dan mi an aal a unu we a di siem iej laik mi, lisn tu wa mi av fi se tu unu.”
When they heard that he addressed them in the Hebrew language, they became even more quiet.Then he said|Wen dem ier se im a taak tu dem iina di Aramik langwij, dem kwaiyat dong iivn muor.Den Paal se

“I am a Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this city. At the feet of Gamaliel I was trained in the strict tradition of the law of the fathers, being zealous toward God as you all are today. |“Mi a wan Juu. Mi baan iina Taasos we de iina Silisiya, bot mi gruo op rait ya-so iina Jeruusilem. Fi mi tiicha a did Gyamieliyel, an im tiich mi fi fala di Laa we Gad gi fi wi faada faada dem, aad aad. An siem laik ou unu siiros bout Gad, a siem so mi did wel siiros tu

I persecuted this Way to the death, arresting and imprisoning both men and women|Mi yuus tu mek piipl we fala di Wie ou Jiizas se piipl fi liv sofa bad bad til dem aal ded, an tai op man an uman, an mek dem get lak op iina prizn.

as even the high priest and the council of elders bear witness of me. From them I received letters to the brothers in Damascus, where I went to take even those who were there and lead them in chains to Jerusalem to be punished.|Di liida fi di priis dem an di uol gruup a elda dem kyan tel unu bout mi kaaz dem did aal gi mi leta fi kyari tu wi breda dem iina Damaskos we a Juu. So mi go de go ares di piipl dem we did a fala di Wie ou Jiizas se dem fi liv an kyari dem kom a Jeruusilem kom ponish dem.

“As I journeyed and came near Damascus, about noon suddenly a great light from heaven shone around me.|“Wen mi did de pan mi wie an aalmuos riich Damaskos, aal av a sodn, wan brait brait lait fram evn kom uova mi, dat a did bout migl die.
I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why do you persecute Me?’|Den mi jrap a grong an ier wan vais se tu mi se, ‘Saal, Saal, wa mek yu a mek mi sofa?’
“I answered, ‘Who are You, Lord?’“He said to me, ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.’ |“So mi aks, ‘A uu yu, Sa?’ Im se tu mi se, ‘Mi a Jiizas di Nazariin we yu a mek sofa.’

Those who were with me saw the light and were afraid, but they did not hear the voice of Him who was speaking to me.|Di man dem we did de de wid mi si di lait, bot dem neva ier di vais we did a taak tu mi.

“I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’“The Lord said to me, ‘Rise and go into Damascus. There you will be told what you have been appointed to do.’ |“So mi aks, ‘Wa mi fi du Laad?’”“Di Laad se tu mi se, ‘Git op an go a Damaskos. Wen yu riich de yu wi ier wa mi pik yu fi du.’

Since I was blinded by the glory of that light, those who were with me led me by the hand into Damascus.|Sins mi kudn si kaaz di brait brait lait we did shain uova mi did blain mi, di man dem we did de de wid mi uol mi an an liid mi go a Damaskos.

“Ananias, a devout man according to the law, who was well spoken of by all the Jews living there|“Wan man niem Ananaiyas, we riili worship Gad an liv di wie ou di Laa se wi fi liv an we aal di Juu we liv de taak gud bout

came and stood by me, and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight.’ And at that moment I looked up at him.|kom tu mi an tan op saida mi. Im se tu mi se, ‘Breda Saal, luk, si agen!’ Siem taim mi luk op an si'im.

“Then he said, ‘The God of our fathers has appointed you to know His will and to see the Just One and to hear His voice|“Den im se tu mi se, ‘Di Gad we wi faada faada dem worship pik yu fi nuo wa im plan fi du, fi si im sorvant we aalwiez du wa im waahn im fi du an fi ier da wan de taak tu yu imself.
for you will be His witness to all men of what you have seen and heard.
column2: Im du dat kaaz im waahn yu fi go tel piipl evriwe wa yu si an wa yu ier.

column1: And now why do you wait? Rise, be baptized and wash away your sins, and call on the name of the Lord.’|So wa yu a wiet fa nou? Git op, kaal pan Gad niem, get baptaiz an mek Gad wash we yu sin.’
“When I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance|“Afta mi go baka Jeruusilem, mi did iina Gad ous a prie an mi get wan vijan.

and saw Him saying to me, ‘Hurry! Get out of Jerusalem immediately, for they will not receive your testimony concerning Me.’|Iina mi vijan mi si di Laad an im se tu mi se, ‘Ori op! Kom outa Jeruusilem faas faas, kaaz dem naa go biliiv wa yu av fi tel dem bout mi.’

“I said, ‘Lord, they know that I imprisoned and beat those who believed in You in every synagogue. |“So mi se tu im se, ‘Laad, aal a dem wel nuo se mi yuus tu go a di Juu dem choch an biit an lak op enibadi we biliiv iina yu.

And when the blood of Your martyr Stephen was shed, I was standing by consenting to his death, guarding the clothes of those who killed him.’|An wen dem did a kil yu sorvant Stiivn, mi did tan op de an did a se ye, im fi ded, an did aal a tek kier a di kluoz fi di man dem we did a kil im.’
“Then He said to me, ‘Depart, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’ ”|“Den di Laad se tu mi, ‘Gwaan, kaaz mi a-go sen yu faar faar tu di piipl dem we a no Juu.’”

They listened to him up to this word, and then they lifted up their voices and said, “Away with such a man from the earth, for he is not fit to live!”|Di kroud did a lisn tu Paal til im taak bout se di Laad sen im tu di piipl we a no Juu. Den dem staat baal out pan tap a dem vais, “Da man ya fi ded, kil im! Aal im so — aal im no fi liv!”
As they shouted and threw off their garments and threw dust into the air|Wail dem did stil a baal out pan tap a dem vais, a bak aaf dem jakit, an a fling dot iina di ier

the commander ordered him to be brought into the barracks and examined with scourging, so that he might learn what crime they were alleging against him. |di ed fi touzn suoja aada di ada suoja dem fi kyari Paal go bak iina di suoja kyamp. Im tel dem fi biit Paal wid wan wip so im wi tel dem wa im du mek di kroud a rail op gens im so.

As they stretched him forward with straps, Paul said to the centurion standing by, “Is it legal for you to flog an uncondemned Roman citizen?”|Afta dem tai im op an chrech im out fi biit im, Paal aks di ed fi onjrid suoja we did tan op de, “Di Laa gi yu no rait fi biit mi, wan man we kom fram Ruom, wen yu no iivn kyari mi go a kuot an se mi gilti fi notn?”

On hearing this, the centurion reported to the commander, saying, “What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen.”|Wen di ed fi onjrid suoja ier dis, im go tu di ed fi touzn suoja an tel im wa im ier an aks im se, “Wa yu a-go du? Yu no nuo se da man ya kom fram Ruom?”
The commander came and said to him, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”He said, “Yes.”|So di ed fi touzn suoja aks Paal, “Tel mi sopm, yu kom fram Ruom?”Paal ansa im se, “Ye man mi kom fram Ruom.”

The commander answered, “I bought my citizenship for a large sum.”So Paul said, “But I was born a citizen.”|Di ed fi touzn suoja se, “Mi did afi pie wan uol iip a moni fi ton Ruoman.” So Paal se, “Bot a Ruom mi baan an gruo.”

Therefore those who were about to examine Paul immediately backed away from him. And the commander feared, knowing that he was a Roman citizen and because he had bound him.|Den di suoja dem we did out fi biit Paal fi mek im taak, dem bak aaf fram im. An di ed fi touzn suoja did fraitn wen im fain out se im did mek dem tai op Paal, wan man we kom fram Ruom.

On the next day, desiring to know exactly why he was accused by the Jews, he released him and ordered the chief priests and all the Sanhedrin to assemble, and he brought Paul down to stand before them.|Di neks die, di ed fi touzn suoja did riili waahn fi nuo wa mek di Juu dem did a go gens Paal. So im let im go an aada di ed priis an di liida dem fi miit. Den im mek Paal tan op infronta dem.

Paul looked at the Sanhedrin and said, “Brothers, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.”|Paal luk chriet pan di liida dem an se tu dem se, “Mi breda, aal a mi laif op tu tide, mi liv rait, an mi kanchens naa go bada mi wen mi tan op infronta Gad.
The high priest Ananias ordered those who stood by him to strike him on the mouth|Wen im se dat, Ananaiyas, di liida fi di priis dem, aada di man dem we did tan op de fi baks Paal pan im mout.

Then Paul said to him, “God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! Do you sit judging me according to the law, yet order me to be struck contrary to the law?”|Den Paal se tu im se, “Gad a-go chraik yu dong, yu wait wash waal yu! Yu sidong de laik wan joj we a du wa di Laa se, bot yu brok di Laa an aada dem fi baks mi?”
Those who stood by said, “Do you criticize God’s high priest?”|Di man dem we did tan op saida im aks im se, “A di liida fi Gad priis dem yu a chat tu so?”

Paul said, “Brothers, I did not know that he was the high priest. For it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil of the ruler of your people.’|Paal ansa se, “Mi breda, mi neva nuo se im a did di liida fi di priis dem, kaaz it rait dong iina Gad wod se, ‘Yu no fi chat bad bout di ruula fi yu piipl.’ ”

Then Paul, knowing that one sect were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, cried out among the Sanhedrin, “Brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of a Pharisee. I am being judged for my hope in the resurrection of the dead.” |Bot wen Paal si se som a dem a did Sadyusii an som a dem a did Farisii, im shout out iina di miitn, “Mi Breda, mi a wan Farisii, an mi faada a wan Farisii tu. A kaaz mi biliiv se ded piipl a-go kom bak alaiv mek dem a joj mi.”

When he had said this, dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.|Wen im se dis, di Sadyusii an di Farisii dem staat kwaril mongks dem wan aneda so di gruup plit op iina tuu.

For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit. But the Pharisees acknowledge them all.|Kaaz di Sadyusii dem se nobadi kyaahn ded an kom bak alaiv, no ienjel no de, ar no spirit no de, bot di Farisii dem biliiv iina aal a dem sitn de.

There was a great outcry. The scribes that were from the sect of Pharisees stood up and argued, “We find no evil in this man. But if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him, let us not fight against God.” |Di Sadyusii dem an di Farisii dem shout aafa wan aneda louda an louda til som a di Laa tiicha fram di Farisii gruup get op an taak chrang chrang, an wan a dem se, “Wi no fain notn rang wid da man ya. Sopuoz a wan spirit ar wan ienjel did taak tu im fi chuu?”

When much dissension arose, fearing that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, the commander ordered the soldiers to go down and take him from them by force and bring him into the barracks.|Wen di kwaril get riili riili bad, di ed fi touzn suoja kech im fried kaaz im tingk se dem wuda tier op Paal. So im aada im suoja dem fi go dong go tek we Paal fram mongks dem an kyari im bak iina di suoja kyamp.

The following night the Lord stood by him and said, “Take courage, Paul. For as you have testified about Me in Jerusalem, so you must also testify at Rome.”|Di neks nait di Laad tan op saida Paal an tel im se, “Tek aat, kaaz siem ou yu tel di Jeruusilem piipl dem bout mi, a siem so yu afi go tel di piipl dem iina Ruom bout mi tu.”

At daybreak some of the Jews conspired under oath, saying they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.|Di neks maanin, di Juu dem mek wan siikrit plan an som a dem swier se tonda ruol an brok dem nek dem naa nyam ar jringk notn til dem kil Paal.
There were more than forty who had conspired.
column2: Yu did av uova faati a dem we se so.

column1: They went to the chief priests and elders and said, “We have bound ourselves under oath not to eat until we have killed Paul. |Dem go tu di ed priis an di elda dem an se tu dem se, “Wi swier se tonda ruol an brok wi nek wi naa nyam ar jringk notn til wi kil Paal.

So now, with the Sanhedrin, tell the commander to bring him down to you tomorrow, pretending to inquire further concerning him. We are ready to kill him before he arrives.”|So wi a aks yu an di liida dem fi beg di ed fi touzn suoja fi kyari im kom dong tu yu laik se yu out fi mek op yu main bout im kies. Tel im se yu waahn fi kwestiyan im som muor. Wi redi fi kil im iivn bifuo im riich nier ya.”

But when the son of Paul’s sister heard of the treachery, he went and entered the barracks and told Paul.|Bot Paal sista bwai pikni ier bout ou dem plan fi gyang Paal, so im go tu di suoja kyamp an go tel Paal bout it.

Then Paul called one of the centurions over and said, “Take this young man to the commander, for he has something to tell him.”|So Paal kaal wan a di ed fi onjrid suoja an se tu im se, “Kyari da yuut man ya tu di ed fi touzn suoja, kaaz im av sopm fi tel im.”

So he took him to the commander and said, “Paul the prisoner sent for me and asked me to bring you this young man who has something to tell you.”|So im kyari im tu ed fi touzn suoja an se tu im se, “Di prizna we niem Paal kaal mi an aks mi fi kyari da yuut man ya tu yu kaaz im av sopm fi tel yu.”
Then the commander took him by the hand, went aside privately, and asked him, “What is it you have to tell me?”|Di ed fi touzn suoja tek im go wan said an aks im se, “Wa yu av fi tel mi?”

The boy said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down tomorrow to the Sanhedrin, pretending to inquire further concerning him.|Im ansa im se, “Di Juu dem plan fi aks yu fi kyari Paal dong tu di liida dem tumaro. Dem plan fi mek it luk laik se dem waahn fi kwestiyan im som muor.

Do not trust them. More than forty men, who have bound themselves with an oath to neither eat nor drink until they have killed him, are waiting for him. And now they are ready, waiting for your promise.”|Bot no mek dem presha yu an yu go du wa dem se, kaaz muor dan faati a dem a aid an a wiet fi gyang im. Dem swier blain se dem naa nyam ar jringk notn til dem kil im. Dem redi an a wiet rait ya nou fi ier ef yu a-go du wa dem a aks yu fi du.”

The commander dismissed the young man and ordered him, “Tell no one that you have reported these things to me.”|Den di ed fi touzn suoja sen we di yuut man afta im tel im se, “No tel nobadi se yu tel mi dem sitn ya.”

Then he summoned two centurions and said, “Prepare two hundred infantrymen, seventy mounted soldiers, and two hundred light infantrymen with spears to go to Caes­area at the third hour of the night.|Afta dat im kaal tuu ed fi onjrid suoja an tel dem se, “Get tuu onjrid suoja, sevnti man we raid aas an tuu onjrid man we fait wid spier an get redi fi go a Sesuriiya nain aklak tinait.
And provide mounts so Paul may ride and take him safely to Felix the governor.”
column2: An av som aas redi fi Paal raid an mek shuor se im riich govana Fiiliks sief.”

column1: He wrote a letter that went like this:
column2: Di ed fi touzn suoja rait wan leta se:

column1: Claudius Lysias,To His Excellency Governor Felix:Greetings.|Govana Fiiliks sa, dis a Klaadiyos Lisiyas.Oudi!

This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them. When I learned that he was a Roman citizen, I came with soldiers and rescued him. |Di Juu dem kyapcha da man ya an did out fi kil im. Bot wen mi lorn se im did kom fram Ruom, mi get wan gruup a suoja an go siev im fram dem.
Being minded to learn what crime they alleged, I took him to their Sanhedrin.|Sins mi did waahn fi nuo wa rang dem did se im did du, mi kyari im go dong tu dem liida.

I found him being accused of controversial matters about their law, but charged with nothing worthy of death or imprisonment. |Mi fain se som a di Juu dem did a aagyu wid im bout som sitn fi du wid dem Laa, bot im neehn du notn fi wi kil im ar lak im op fa.

When it was revealed to me that there was a plot against the man, at once I sent him to you and ordered the accusers to state before you their charges against him.Farewell.|Wen mi lorn se dem did a set op wan siikrit plan fi kil di man, mi sen im tu yu siem taim an aada im enimi dem fi kom tu yu kom saat out dem prablem.
So the soldiers, according to their orders, took Paul by night to Antipatris.|So di suoja dem du we di ed fi onjrid suoja aada dem fi du. Dem tek Paal iina di nait an kyari im go tu Antipachris.
The next day they let the cavalry depart with him and they returned to the barracks.
column2: Di neks die dem mek di man dem we raid di aas dem go wid Paal an di ada man dem go baka Jeruusilem.

column1: When they arrived in Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also to him.|Wen di man dem we raid pan aas riich a Sesuriiya, dem gi di govana di leta an lef Paal iina im an.

Upon reading the letter, the governor asked what province he was from. When he learned that he was from Cilicia|Afta di govana riid di leta, im aks Paal wich konchri im kom fram. Wen im fain out se Paal kom fram Silisiya

he said, “I will hear you when your accusers also arrive.” And he ordered that he be guarded in Herod’s Praetorium.|im se, “Wen di piipl dem we a se yu du rang kom, mi wi joj wa yu av fi se fi yuself.” Den im gi aada fi dem kip Paal anda gyaad iina di palis we Erad did bil.
After five days Ananias the high priest arrived with some of the elders and a lawyer named Tertullus. They brought before the governor their charges against Paul.
column2: Afta faiv die Ananaiyas di liida fi di priis dem kom dong wid som elda an wan laaya niem Tortyuulos an dem tel di govana bout di prablem dem av wid Paal.

column1: When he was summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, “Since through you we enjoy much peace, and your foresight is bringing reforms to this nation|Afta dem kyari iin Paal Tortyuulos staat fi chat gens im. Im se tu di govana se, “Yu a wan waiz liida. Siek-a dat fi wan lang lang taim nou wi av piis iina wi konchri. An yu kaaz nof gud sitn fi apm sins yu staat ruul.
with all thankfulness, most excellent Felix, we always welcome it everywhere.|Govana Fiiliks, Sa, yu du aal kain-a gud sitn. Wi si dem, an wi si dem evriwe an wi tangk yu wid aal a wi aat.

But not to detain you further, I beg you to briefly hear us in your patience.|Bot mi no waahn tek op tu moch a yu taim, so mi a beg yu, lisn tu wi likl bit muor kaaz yu aalwiez shuo gud fies aal wen wi no dizorv it.

“We have found this man a troublemaker, instigating riots among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes. |“Wi fain se da man ya a wan wikid wikid chobl-meka we a rail op di Juu dem aal uova di worl, an im a wan ring liida fi wan paati we dem kaal di Nazariin.
He even tried to profane the temple. So we seized him and wanted to judge him according to our law.|Im aal chrai fi doti op Gad ous an no mek it kliin no muor, so wi kech im.
But the commander, Lysias, came to us and forcefully took him out of our hands|Den dem komaanda, Laisias kom tu wi an grab im we frahn wi.
ordering his accusers to come before you. By examining him yourself you will be able to learn about all these things concerning which we accuse him.
column2: Bot wen yu kwestiyan im fi yuself yu wi lorn se aal a dem sitn ya wa wi a tel yu bout a riili chuu.”

column1: The Jews assented, alleging these things to be true.|Aal di Juu dem jain iin an se di sitn dem we im did a se bout Paal a chuu.

After the governor motioned to him to speak, Paul answered, “Knowing that for many years you have been a judge over this nation, I cheerfully defend myself.|Wen di govana paint pan Paal an gi im di chaans fi taak fi imself, Paal se: “Mi nuo se a lang lang taim nou yu a sorv az joj uova da konchri ya, so mi api fi taak op fi miself.
You may verify that it is no more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
column2: Yu kyan fain out iizi iizi se no muor dan twelv die nou mi go op tu Jeruusilem fi go worship Gad.

column1: They did not find me in the temple or in the synagogues or in the city disputing with anyone or stirring up a crowd.|Dem neva fain mi a aagyu wid nobadi ar a rail op no kroud iina Gad ous, iina di Juu dem choch, ar no we els iina di siti.
They cannot prove the things concerning which they now accuse me.
column2: An dem kyaahn pruuv tu yu aal di sitn dem we dem a tel yu se mi du.

column1: However, I affirm that in accordance with the Way, which they call a sect, I worship the God of my fathers and believe everything written in the Law and in the Prophets. |Bot wa mi kyan se tu yu a dis, mi worship di Gad we wi faada faada dem worship azkaadn tu da Wie de — di Wie we dem se rang. Mi biliiv evriting we iina di Laa an we di prafit dem rait dong.

I have hope in God that there will be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and the unjust, which they also expect.|Mi an dem man ya biliiv di siem ting. Wi a wiet an a luk fi Gad mek ded piipl kom bak alaiv, weda dem did gud ar bad.
In this do I always strive to have a clear conscience toward God and toward men.
column2: A dat mek mi aalwiez du mi bes fi liv rait so dat nobadi kyaahn paint no fingga pan mi an mi kyan tan op infronta Gad an mi kanchens no bada mi.

column1: “Now after many years I came to bring alms and offerings to my nation|“Afta mi did kip we fram Jeruusilem fi kopl ier, mi go bak fi kyari som moni fi gi mi uona piipl fi elp di puor an fi bon sakrifais gi Gad.

when some Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with a crowd nor an uproar.|A dat mi did a du wen dem si mi iina Gad ous. Dat taim de mi did don du aal we mi did sopuoz fi du fi mek miself kliin iina Gad yai. Mi neva av no kroud wid mi, an mi neva du notn fi kaaz no chobl niida.
They ought to be here before you to accuse me if they have any charges.|Bot yu av som Juu fram Iezha we shuda de ya infronta yu nou, ef dem av notn gens mi.
Or let these men say what crime they found in me when I stood before the Sanhedrin
column2: Ar dem man ya shuda tel yu wa rang dem did fain se mi du wen mi did tan op infronta dem liida.

column1: unless it is concerning this one statement which I cried out while standing among them, ‘Concerning the resurrection of the dead, I am being judged by you this day.’ ”|Di onggl ting dem kyan se a dat mi baal out iina dem miitn an se: ‘A kaaz mi biliiv se ded piipl a-go kom bak alaiv mek unu de ya tide a joj mi.’ ”

When Felix, who had more exact knowledge concerning the Way, had heard this, he adjourned the proceedings and said, “When Lysias the commander arrives, I will decide your case.” |Den Fiiliks, we nuo di chuut bout di Laad Wie tap wa did a gwaan, don kuot an se, “Wen Lisiyas di ed fi touzn suoja kom, mi wi mek op mi main bout wa mi a-go du wid yu.”

Then he ordered the centurion to guard Paul, and to let him have liberty, and to forbid none of his own people from attending to him.|So im aada di ed fi onjrid suoja fi gyaad Paal, bot fi gi im likl spies, an no tap non a im fren dem fram elp im non at aal.

After several days, when Felix arrived with his wife Drusilla, who was a Jewess, he sent for Paul and heard him speak concerning faith in Christ.|Kopl die afta dat wen Fiiliks an im waif Jruusila, we a wan Juu uman riich, im sen fi Paal. Im lisn wen Paal taak bout wa it miin fi biliiv iina Jiizas Krais.

As he lectured about righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix was afraid and answered, “For now, leave! When time permits, I will send for you.” |Wail Paal did a taak bout wa it miin fi sumadi du we rait, kanchuol demself, an di die wen Gad a-go joj evribadi fi aal we dem du, weda gud ar bad, Fiiliks kech im fried an se tu Paal se, “Dat inof fi nou. Yu kyan lef. Wen mi fain taim mi wi sen fi yu agen.”

At the same time he hoped that money would be given him by Paul, that he might release him. So he sent for him more often and conversed with him.|Bot im did a uop se Paal wuda pie im aaf fi im let im go, so im sen fi im an taak wid im agen an agen.

But after two years Porcius Festus succeeded Felix. And Felix, desiring to do the Jews a favor, left Paul imprisoned.|Afta tuu ier paas, Porshiyos Festos ton di nyuu govana an tek uova fram Fiiliks. Bot kaaz Fiiliks did a chrai fi kori fieva wid di Juu dem, im lef Paal iina prizn.
Now three days after Festus had come into the province, he went from Caesarea up to Jerusalem.|Chrii die afta Festos riich iina di konchri, im go a Jeruusilem fram Sesuriiya.
The high priest and the elders of the Jews spoke to him against Paul. And they begged him
column2: So di ed priis an di impuotant man dem mongks di Juu dem kom faawod an tel im di prablem dem av wid Paal.

column1: asking as a favor against him, that he would summon him to Jerusalem, plotting to kill him along the way.|Dem beg Festos fi du sitn speshal fi dem. Dem beg im fi gi aada fi Paal kom baka Jeruusilem. Dem du dat kaaz dem did av a plan fi gyang op an kil im bifuo im kuda riich.
Festus said that Paul should be kept at Caesarea and that he himself intended to go there shortly.|Den Festos tel dem se, “Paal de a prizn a Sesuriiya an mi out fi go dong de suun.

He also said, “Let the men in authority go down with me. If there is anything wrong in the man, let them accuse him.”|So mek unu liida dem go dong de wid mi an ef da man ya did du notn rang, dem kyan se wa im du.”

Having stayed among them more than ten days, he went down to Caesarea. And the next day he sat on the judgment seat and ordered that Paul be brought in.|Afta Festos tan mongks dem fi bout iet ar ten die im lef an go a Sesuriiya. Di neks die im tek im siit iina di kuot an gi aada fi Paal kom infronta im so im kyan joj im.

When he arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him and brought many serious charges against him which they could not prove|Wen Paal kom iin, di Juu dem we did kom dong fram Jeruusilem tan op roun im. Dem staat tel di govana som torbl sitn we dem se Paal du. Bot dem kudn pruuv notn we dem se.

while he defended himself, saying, “Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar have I sinned at all.”|So Paal taak op fi imself an se, “Mi no du notn rang gens di Juu dem, mi no brok non a dem Laa, ar du notn we wuda mek Gad ous no kliin no muor, ar se notn bad gens Siiza.”

Desiring to do the Jews a favor, Festus answered, “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem to be judged concerning these charges before me?”|Bot Festos did a chrai fi kori fieva wid di Juu dem, so im aks Paal se, “Yu waahn fi go a Jeruusilem an mek mi joj yu an si ef aal wa dem a se bout yu a chuu ar a no chuu?”

Paul said, “I am standing before Caesar’s judgment seat, where I ought to be judged. I have done no wrong to the Jews, as you know very well.|Paal ansa im se, “Mi tan op iina Siiza kuot rait ya nou an a ya-so mi fi get joj. Mi no du notn rang tu di Juu dem, an yu wel an nuo dat.

If I am doing wrong or have done anything worthy of death, I do not refuse to die. But if these are empty charges of which these men accuse me, no one may deliver me to them. I appeal to Caesar.”|Ef mi rang an du notn we dem shuda kil mi fa, mi naa chrai fi ron we. Bot ef mi neva du non a di sitn dem we dem se, nobadi kyaahn ton mi uova tu dem. So sen mi go a Siiza, mek im joj mi.”

When Festus had conferred with the council, he then answered, “To Caesar you have appealed. To Caesar you shall go.”|So afta Festos taak wid di man dem we elp im fi mek op im main bout wa im a-go du, im se, “Yu se yu waahn mi sen yu go a Siiza, so a Siiza mi a sen yu!”
After several days King Agrippa and Bernice arrived at Caesarea to welcome Festus. |Afta kopl die wel, King Agripa an Borniis kom a Sesuriiya fi welkom Festos.

When they had been there many days, Festus stated Paul’s case to the king, saying, “There is a man left as a prisoner by Felix. |Afta dem did de de fi a gud wail, Festos tel di King bout Paal, di Juu dem, an aal wa did a gwaan, kaaz im did waahn fi nuo wa di King tingk. So im tel im se, “Fiiliks lef wan prizna ya.

When I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me about him, asking for a sentence against him.|Wen mi did de a Jeruusilem, di ed priis an di Juu elda dem tel mi bout im, an aks mi fi joj im an se im gilti.

“I answered, ‘It is not the custom of the Romans to deliver any man to die before he who is accused meets the accusers face to face and has the opportunity to make his defense concerning the charge brought against him.’ |“Bot mi tel dem se Ruoman piipl no joj nobadi an se dem gilti jos so. Dem afi get di chaans fi tan op infronta di piipl dem we se dem du sitn rang, an taak op fi demself.

So when they assembled here, without delay I sat on the judgment seat the next day and ordered that the man be brought in. |So afta dem kom ya wid mi, mi neva wies no taim. Di neks die mi gi aada fi dem bring im a kuot fi mi joj im.

When the accusers stood up, they brought no accusation against him of such crimes as I had supposed. |Bot wen di Juu liida dem taak op gens im, di wikid sitn dem we mi did tingk se dem wuda se im du a no dat dem se.

But they had disagreements with him about their own religion and about a Man named Jesus, who had died, but whom Paul asserted was alive.|Insted-a dat, dem did a aagyu wid im bout sopm fi du wid di wie ou dem worship Gad an bout wan ded man niem Jiizas we Paal se kom bak alaiv.

Being perplexed about such questions, I asked if he would be willing to go to Jerusalem and be tried there concerning these charges. |Mi neva nuo ou fi diil wid di mata, so mi aks di man ef im did waahn fi go a Jeruusilem an mek mi joj im de-so.

But when Paul had appealed to be under guard for the decision of Caesar, I ordered that he be secured until I could send him to Caesar.”|Bot wen Paal aks mi fi uol im til Siiza kuda joj im, mi gi aada fi dem gyaad im so til mi kuda sen im go a Siiza.”

Then Agrippa said to Festus, “I would like to hear the man myself.”He said, “Tomorrow you shall hear him.”|Den King Agripa se tu Festos, “Mi wuda laik fi ier da man ya miself.” So Festos tel im se, “Aarait, tumaro yu wi ier im.”

The next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp, and they entered the hall with the commanders and the leading men of the city. When Festus gave the order, Paul was brought in.|Di neks die wen King Agripa an Borniis did a kom di piipl dem du aal saat a sitn fi big dem op an welkom dem. So dem go iina di plies we di piipl dem gyada op fi kip kuot. Aal a di ed fi touzn suoja an di big impuotant man dem iina di siti go wid dem tu. Den Festos aada di suoja dem fi kyari iin Paal.

Festus said, “King Agrippa, and all the men who are present with us, you see this man, concerning whom the whole assembly of the Jews petitioned me, both at Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.|Den Festos se, “King Agripa, an evribadi we de ya wid wi, unu si da man ya, aal a di Juu dem beg mi loud loud no fi mek im liv no langga. Dem beg mi wen mi did de a Jeruusilem an dem beg mi dong ya iina Sesuriiya.

I found that he had committed nothing worthy of death. But when he himself appealed to Caesar, I decided to send him. |Bot mi fain se im no du notn we wi fi kil im fa, an wen im se im waahn di Ruula Siiza imself fi joj im, mi mek op mi main fi sen im.

But I have nothing to write to His Majesty concerning him. Therefore I have brought him before you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that upon examination, I might have something to write. |Bot mi no riili av notn we mi kyan rait bout im an sen gi mi Laad. So mi kyari im kom ya infronta aal a unu, an muo dan dat mi kyari im infronta yu, King Agripa, so dat afta yu ier im da fos taim ya, mi mait-a av sopm fi rait.
For it seems unreasonable to me to send a prisoner without signifying the charges against him.”
column2: Kaaz mi no tingk it rait fi sen wan prizna an kyaahn se fi shuor wa rang dem se im du.”

column1: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You are permitted to speak for yourself.”So Paul stretched out his hand and made his defense:|Den Agripa se tu Paal se, “Yu kyan taak fi yuself nou.” So Paal riez im an an staat taak op. Im se

“King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that today I shall make my defense before you against all the accusations of the Jews|“King Agripa, mi tingk mi wel loki tide fi get di chaans fi taak op fi miself infronta yu bout aal a wa di Juu dem se mi du

especially because you are an expert in all customs and controversies of the Jews. Therefore I beg you to patiently listen to me.|kaaz mi nuo se yu wel nuo bout ou di Juu dem liv an bout aal di sitn dem we dem aagyu bout. So mi a beg yu du, tek taim an lisn mi.

“My manner of life from my youth, spent from the beginning in my own nation and at Jerusalem, is known by all the Jews. |“Nou aal di Juu dem nuo ou mi liv fram mi a likl bwai — fram mi a likl bwai a gruo op iina mi uona konchri an iina Jeruusilem.

They knew me from the beginning and could testify, if they wished, how according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived as a Pharisee. |Dem nuo, kaaz dem nuo mi fram lang lang taim. An ef dem waahn dem kyan tel yu ou mi liv azkaadn tu di gruup mongks wi piipl we fala di Laa tu a tii, kaaz mi a wan Farisii.
And now I stand on trial for hope in the promise made by God to our fathers
column2: Nou dem a joj mi kaaz mi biliiv an a luk fi get di sitn dem we Gad pramis fi gi wi faada faada dem.

column1: to which our twelve tribes hope to attain, as they earnestly serve God day and night. Concerning this hope, King Agrippa, I am accused by the Jews.|Yu ana, a da siem pramis ya di twelv chraib a wi piipl dem a luk fi get. A dat mek dem gwaan sorv Gad nait an die. A siek-a wa mi a luk fi get fram Gad mek di Juu dem a se di sitn dem we dem a se gens mi.
Why is it judged incredible by you that God raises the dead?
column2: Wa mek unu Juu mek op unu main no fi biliiv se Gad mek sumadi we ded kom bak alaiv?

column1: “I, too, thought that I must do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth|“A siem so mi did biliiv se mi did afi du evriting we mi kuda du fi ort Jiizas we kom fram Nazaret.

which I indeed did in Jerusalem and locked up many of the saints in prison by authority from the chief priests. And when they were killed, I cast my vote against them.|An a dat mi yuus tu du iina Jeruusilem. Mi neva jos get powa fram di ed priis fi lak op som a di piipl dem we biliiv, bot mi aal vuot gens dem wen dem sen dem fi ded.

I punished them often in every synagogue and compelled them to blaspheme. And being extremely enraged against them, I persecuted them even to foreign cities.|Mi ponish dem nof taim iina di Juu dem choch an chrai fi get dem fi ton we fram Jiizas an se dem no biliiv iina im no muor. Mi did so mad wid dem mi go afta dem aal iina farin konchri fi mek dem sofa.
“So I went to Damascus with authority and a commission from the chief priests.|“A dat mi did a go a Damaskos fa, an di ed priis dem did gi mi wan leta we gi mi di powa fi dwi'it.

At midday, O King, I saw along the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those who journeyed with me. |Bot yu ana, bout twelv aklak wen mi did de pan mi wie, mi si wan brait brait lait fram evn, braita dan di son kom uova mi an uova di man dem we did de de wid mi.

When we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why do you persecute Me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’|Aal a wi jrap a grong, an mi ier sumadi se tu mi iina di Aramik langwij se, ‘Saal, Saal, wa mek yu a mek mi sofa? A ort yu a ort yuself wen yu du dat. Dat komiin laik se yu a kik gens wan shaap shaap tik.’
“I said, ‘Who are You, Lord?’“He said, ‘I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.|“So mi aks ‘A uu yu, Sa?’ Di Laad ansa mi se, “‘Mi a Jiizas we yu a mek sofa.

But rise and stand on your feet. For I have appeared to you for this purpose, to appoint you as a servant and a witness both of what you have seen and of what I will yet reveal to you. |Bot git op tan op kaaz mi pik yu fi shuo miself tu yu. Mi du dat fi mek yu wan a mi sorvant fi go tel piipl bout di sitn dem we yu si an we mi a-go shuo yu.
I will deliver you from your people and from the Gentiles to whom I now send you|Mi a-go siev yu fram yu uona piipl an fram di piipl we a no Juu, we mi a-go sen yu tu.

to open their eyes and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in Me.’|Mi a sen yu tu dem so yu kyan elp dem fi si an kom outa di daaknis an kom iina di lait. An mi a sen yu fi elp dem get frii fram Sietan powa an mek Gad ruul dem laif. Da wie de dem wi ton paat a Gad piipl uufa sin im paadn kaaz dem biliiv iina im.’
“Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision|“So King Agripa, di wan we kom fram evn we mi si iina mi vijan, mi du wa im se.

but declared first to those at Damascus, then at Jerusalem and throughout all the region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God and do works proving their repentance.|So di fos plies mi priich a Damaskos. Afta dat mi priich iina Jeruusilem an aal uova Judiya. Mi priich tu di piipl we a no Juu tu. Mi tel dem fi ton we fram dem sin an ton tu Gad an fi du di sitn dem we shuo se dem riili sari bout dem sin.
For these reasons the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
column2: A dat di Juu dem ares mi fa wen mi did de iina Gad ous an a dat mek dem did a chrai fi kil mi.

column1: Therefore having obtained help from God, I continue to this day, testifying both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said would happen:|Tu da die ya Gad a elp mi an so mi tan op infronta aal a unu, weda unu impuotant ar no impuotant, fi taak di chuut. Di siem ting wa Muoziz an di prafit dem did se a-go apm, a di siem ting mi a se.

that the Christ must suffer, that He would be the first who would rise from the dead, and would announce light to His own people and to the Gentiles.”|Dem se di wan we Gad sen fi siev piipl did afi ded so im kuda bi di fos wan fi kom bak alaiv an fi mek piipl we a Juu an piipl we a no Juu nuo se dem kyan get siev, an da mesij de a-go komiin laik lait tu dem.”

So as he made his defense, Festus said with a loud voice, “Paul, you are mad. Much learning is turning you to madness.”|Wail Paal did a taak, Festos kaal out pan tap a im vais, “Paal, yu mad. Yu ed a tek yu! Yu lorn tu moch an yu ed a tek yu nou!”
Paul said, “I am not mad, most excellent Festus. I speak the words of truth and reason.|Bot Paal ansa im se, “Anarebl Festos sa, mi no mad. Wa mi a se a chuu, mi naa taak no fuulinish.

The king, before whom I also speak freely, knows about these things. For I am persuaded that none of this is hidden from him, for this was not done in a corner.|Mi naa taak no fuulinish, kaaz di King nuo bout aal a dem sitn ya, so mi a taak tu im an naa uol notn bak, kaaz mi shuor se non a dem sitn ya no apm we im no nuo bout, kaaz dem neva apm iina wan kaana.
King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe.”|King Agripa, yu biliiv wa di prafit dem rait? Mi nuo se yu biliiv.”
Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You almost persuade me to be a Christian.”|Agripa se tu Paal se, “So iina no taim yu a chrai ton mi iina sumadi we biliiv iina Jiizas?”

Paul said, “I pray to God that not only you, but all who hear me this day, might become not only almost, but thoroughly and altogether, what I am, except for these chains.”|So Paal ansa se, “Mi prie Gad se no onggl yu bot aal uu a lisn mi tide wuda ton jos laik mi, weda iina no taim ar aal ef it tek lang. A onggl wan ting mi no waahn, mi no waahn unu fi chien op laik mi.”
When he had said this, the king rose, as well as the governor and Bernice and those who sat with them.|So di King, di govana, Borniis an aal uu did sidong de wid dem get op

When they had gone aside, they said to one another, “This man is doing nothing deserving death or imprisonment.”|an wen dem did a lef dem se tu dem wan aneda se, “Da man ya naa du notn we im shuda get lak op fa, ar we im fi ded fa.”
And Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”|Agripa se tu Festos se, “Ef da man ya neva aks fi Siiza di ruula joj im, wi kuda let im go.”

When it was decided that we should sail into Italy, they handed Paul and some other prisoners over to a centurion of the Augustan Regiment, named Julius. |Afta dem mek op dem main se wi shuda siel go Itali, dem ton Paal an som ada prizna uova tu Juuliyos wan ed fi onjrid suoja. Im a did paat a di ruula big big gruup a suoja.

Boarding a ship from Adramyttium, we put out to sea, meaning to sail along the coasts of Asia. Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, was with us.|Wi go pan wan ship we did a kom fram Ajramitiyom. Di ship did plan fi tap a som difrant difrant plies pan di Iezha sii kuos. So wi siel out an Ieristaakos fram Masiduoniya we iina Tesalonaika go wid wi.
The next day we landed at Sidon. And Jul­ius treated Paul kindly and gave him leave to go to his friends and be given care.
column2: Di neks die wi tap a Saidan. Juuliyos did kain tu Paal an lou im fi go luk fi im fren dem so dem kuda gi im di sitn dem we im niid.

column1: From there we put out to sea and sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.|Afta dat wi siel out an stie pan di sief said a Saipros kaaz di briiz did tuu chrang fi wi.
Sailing across the sea off of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.|Afta wi siel paas Silisiya an Pamfiliya, wi tap a Maira iina Lishiya.

There the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing to Italy, and he put us on board. |Wen wi tap a Maira di ed fi onjrid suoja si wan ship fram Aligzanjriya we did a go a Itali, so im put wi pan it.

We sailed slowly for many days, and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, and as the wind did not allow us to proceed, we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmone.|Di briiz did so chrang dat fi kopl die, wi did afi siel sluo sluo so wi bieli manij fi riich nier Naidos toun. Kaaz di briiz did stil so chrang, wi kudn go no forda, wi did afi siel pan di sief said a Kriit nier Salmuoni.

Sailing past it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.|Wi gwaan siel pan di sief said a Kriit an bieli manij fi riich a wan plies niem Fier Ievnz nier Lasiiya toun.

As much time had been lost and as the voyage was now dangerous, because the Day of Atonement was already over, Paul advised them|Nof die did paas an it neva sief fi dem siel no muor kaaz di speshal die wen piipl go fi get dem sin paadn did paas. So Paal waan dem se

saying, “Men, I perceive that this voyage will be with injury and much loss, not only of the cargo and ship, but also of our lives.” |“Man, ou mi si'it, ef wi gwaan siel it naa go ton out gud fi wi. Di ship an evriting we wi a kyari a-go mash op an nof piipl a-go ded.”
But the centurion was persuaded more by the captain and the owner of the ship than by what Paul said.|Bot insted-a lisn tu Paal, di ed fi onjrid suoja lisn wa di kyaptin an di man we uon di ship se.

Since the harbor was not suitable to winter in, the majority decided to sail on from there, if somehow we might reach Phoenix, a harbor in Crete, facing southwest and northwest, and winter there.|Kaaz we di ship did de neva sief fi spen di winta, muos a uu did de pan di ship mek op dem main se dem naa tan de, so di kyaptin siel out. Dem did a luk se som ou dem wuda riich Fiiniks nier Kriit we di briiz did a bluo fram an spen di winta de.

When a south wind blew gently, supposing that they had obtained the necessary conditions, they weighed anchor and sailed along the shore of Crete.|Wen wan briiz we neva so chrang staat bluo fram di sout, dem tingk se dem kuda siel out laik ou dem did plan, so dem jraa op di ship angka an siel out. Bot dem kip nier Kriit shuor.
But soon afterward a tempestuous wind swept through, called the Euroclydon.|No tuu lang afta dat wan powaful staam niem di “Naatiista” bluo dong kraas Kriit.
When the ship was overpowered and could not head into the wind, we let her drift.|Di ship get kech op iina di staam an kudn manij it, so wi gi op an mek di staam bluo wi we it waahn wi go.
Drifting under the lee of an island called Cauda, we could scarcely secure the rowboat. |Wi siel paas wan likl ailan niem Kyaada, we wi bieli manij fi kanchuol di likl buot fi di ship an kip it sief.

When they had ­hoisted it aboard, they used ropes to undergird the ship. And fearing that they might run aground on the sand of Syrtis, they let down the mast, and so were driven.|Afta dem lif op di likl buot put pan di ship, dem yuuz ruop anda di ship fi tai it op. Dem du dat kaaz dem did fried di ship mait go jam iina di san il nier Libiya we di waata neva diip. Den dem jrap angka an mek di briiz gwaan bluo di ship.

We were violently tossed by the storm. The next day they threw cargo overboard.|Di neks die di wie di staam did a bata di ship so bad, dem staat fling som a di sitn dem we did de pan di ship iina di sii.
On the third day we threw the tackle of the ship overboard with our own hands.|An pan di tord die, dem siem wan tek op som a di sitn dem we a paat a di ship an fling dem iina di sii.

When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small storm was upon us, all hope that we should be saved was lost.|Afta wi kudn si no son ar staar fi wan lang lang taim, an di staam kip aan a bata wi, wi did shuor se wi don fa, notn kudn siev wi.

After they had long abstained from food, Paul stood in their midst and said, “Men, you should have listened to me and not have set sail from Crete, incurring this injury and loss.|Nof a di man dem neva fiil fi notn fi iit, so Paal tan op mongks dem an se tu dem se, “Unu shuda did lisn tu mi man wen mi did tel unu se wi neva did fi lef outa Kriit. Kaaz ef unu did lisn, wi neva wuda sofa so an luuz so moch.
But now I advise you to take courage, for there will be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.|Bot lisn tu mi nou, tek aat, kaaz non a wi naa go ded, bot di uol ship a-go mash op.
For there stood by me this night the angel of God to whom I belong and whom I serve
column2: Mi nuo dat kaaz laas nait di Gad we mi bilang tu an we mi sorv sen wan ienjel tu mi an im se tu mi se

column1: saying, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand before Caesar. And, look! God has given you all those who sail with you.’ |‘No fried Paal! Yu afi go tan op infronta Siiza, an Gad so gud iivn duo piipl no dizorv it, im naa go mek non a di man dem we a siel wid yu ded.’

Therefore, men, take courage, for I believe God that it will be exactly as it was told to me. |So unu tek aat man, kaaz mi chos iina Gad. An mi shuor se evriting a-go ton out siem laik ou im tel mi se it wuda go.
Nevertheless, we must be shipwrecked on a certain island.”|Bot di ship a-go krash pan wan ailan.”

When the fourteenth night came, while we were drifting in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors supposed that they were approaching land.|Wan nait, afta wi did de a sii fi tuu wiik, di staam did a bluo wi kraas di Ajriyatik Sii. Wen it did riich bout migl nait, di siela dem did biliiv se dem de nier lan.

They took soundings and found the water to be one hundred and twenty feet deep. When they had gone a little farther, they took soundings again and found it to be ninety feet deep.|So dem jrap wan ruop wid sitn evi tai pan it fi chek ou diip di waata bi. Dem fain out se dem did de iina waata we did wan onjrid an twenti fut diip. Afta dem siel likl forda dem chek agen an fain out se di waata did nainti fut diip.

Fearing that we might run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for day to come. |Dem did fried se wi did a-go krash pan di riif, so dem jrap fuo a di ship angka dem fram di baka di ship, an prie fi die lait.

When the sailors strove to abandon ship and lowered the rowboat into the sea, under the pretext of lowering anchors out of the bow|Di siela dem did waahn fi get we fram di ship, so dem let dong di likl buot iina di waata an gwaan laik se a angka dem did a chuo fram infronta di ship.

Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, “Unless these sailors remain in the ship, you cannot be saved.” |Bot Paal se tu di ed fi onjrid suoja se, “Ef di siela dem no tan pan di ship yu kyaahn riich a shuor alaiv.”
Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the rowboat and let her fall off.
column2: So di suoja dem kot di ruop dem we did tai op di buot an mek it jrap iina di waata an bluo we.

column1: As day was about to dawn, Paul asked them all to eat, saying, “Today is the fourteenth day that you have waited and continued without food, having eaten nothing.|Wen die suun lait, Paal beg dem fi iit sopm. Im se, “Tide mek fuotiin die sins unu a wori unuself an no iit notn.

So I urge you to eat. This is for your preservation, for not a hair shall fall from your head.” |So unu kom aan nou man, iit sopm, ar unu naa go mek it. An non a unu naa go luuz no iivn wan dege-dege ier aafa unu ed.”

When he had said this, he took some bread and gave thanks to God in the presence of them all. And when he had broken it he began to eat. |Afta im se dat, Paal tek bred an gi Gad tangks infronta aal a dem. Den im brok it an staat fi iit it.
Then they were all encouraged, and they also ate food themselves. |So aal a dem tek aat an iit sopm tu.
In all we were two hundred and seventy-six persons on the ship.
column2: A did tuu onjrid an sevnti-siks a wi de pan di ship.

column1: When they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and threw the wheat into the sea.|Afta dem don nyam aal wa dem waahn, dem fling di res a sitn dem pan di ship iina di waata.

When it was day, they did not recognize the land. But they noticed a bay with a shore, into which they were determined to run the ship if possible. |Wen die lait, dem neva nuo wich paat dem did de, bot dem si wan ieriya we luk laik wan bie wid wan biich. So dem mek op dem main fi chrai an ron di ship pan di san bangk.

Casting off the anchors, they left them in the sea while loosening the ropes that secured the rudders. Then they hoisted the mainsail to the wind and made for shore. |So dem kot aaf di angka dem aafa di ruop an lef dem iina di sii. Dem luus di chien aafa di sitn dem we fi ton di ship, put op di big big piis a klaat we dem yuuz fi kech di briiz, ton roun di ship an ed fi di biich.

But striking a sandbar where two seas met, they ran the ship aground. The bow stuck and remained immovable, but the stern was broken up by the violent surf.|Bot dem ron iina di san wich paat di waata shalo. Di fronta di ship jam an faasn iina di san an kudn muuv. Di wiev dem krash so aad gens di baka di ship dat it brok op iina piisiz.
The soldiers’ plan was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim away and escape.|So di suoja dem plan fi kil di prizna dem so dat non a dem kudn jomp iina di sii an get we.

But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, prevented them from their intent and ordered those who could swim to abandon ship first and get to land|Bot di ed fi onjrid suoja neva waahn dem fi kil Paal, so im neva mek di suoja dem kil non a di prizna dem. So im gi aada se aal uu kyan swim fi jomp aaf fos an swim go a lan
and the rest on planks or on pieces of the ship. And in this way they all escaped safely to land.
column2: an di wan dem we kyaahn swim fi eng aan pan piis a plangk ar eniting we brok aafa di ship an fluot go a shuor. An a so aal a dem riich lan sief.

column1: When they had escaped, they learned that the island was called Malta.|Afta aal a wi riich shuor sief, wi fain out fram di piipl dem se di ailan niem Maalta.

The natives showed extraordinary kindness, for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all, because of the rain and the cold. |Di piipl dem shuo wi gud fies an chriit wi wel gud. An kaaz rien did staat faal an it did kuol, dem kech op faiya fi wi.

When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and put them on the fire, a viper driven out by the heat fastened on his hand. |Paal pik op wan bongl a bram-bram an put it pan di faiya. Wen im du dat, di faiya iit kaaz wan siniek fi kom out an grab aan pan Paal an.

When the natives saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “Surely this man is a murderer. Though he has escaped from the sea, justice does not allow him to live.” |Wen di piipl si se di siniek eng an pan Paal an, dem se tu wan aneda se, “Da man ya a mos wan mordara! Iivn duo im get we fram di sii, di gad we niem Jostis se im no fi liv.”
But he shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.
column2: Bot Paal shiek im aaf iina di faiya an notn neva du im.

column1: They expected him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But while they waited and saw no harm befall him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.|Bot di piipl did a luk fi si im swel op ar jrap dong ded siem taim. Bot afta dem wiet fi wan lang taim an no si notn apm tu im, dem chienj dem main an se im a wan gad.

In that area was an estate of the chief man of the island, named Publius, who had welcomed us and courteously housed us for three days. |Kluos tu we dat did apm tu Paal, wan man niem Pyuubliyos did av im ous an lan. Im a did di ed fi di govament fi di ailan. Im tek wi iina im ous an tek gud kier a wi. An wi tan a im ous fi chrii die.

It happened that the father of Publius lay sick with a fever and dysentery. Paul visited him and, placing his hands on him, prayed and healed him.|Pyuubliyos faada did sik an iina bed. Im di av fiiva an wan siknis we mek im beli ron an kaaz im fi vamit. Paal go iin go si im an afta im prie fi im, im put im an pan im an mek im beta.
When this happened, the rest on the island who had diseases also came and were healed. |Afta dat uol iip a piipl pan di ailan we did sik kom tu Paal fi im mek dem beta.
They honored us in many ways. And when we sailed, they provided us with necessary supplies.|Di piipl dem shuo wi nof rispek an wen wi did out fi lef, dem gi wi evriting we wi did niid.

After three months we sailed in an Alexandrian ship whose figurehead was the Twin Brothers, which had wintered at the island. |Afta wi spen chrii mont de, wi lef iina wan ship we did kom fram Aligzanjriya an we did de pan di ailan fi di winta. Di ship di niem “Di Twin Gad.”
Landing at Syracuse, we waited there for three days.|Wi tap iina Sirakyuus aaba an tan de fi chrii die.

From there we circled around and sailed to Rhegium. After one day the south wind blew, and the next day we arrived at Puteoli.|Wi lef de-so an siel tu Rejiyom siti. Di neks die wan chrang chrang briiz we bluo fram di sout tek wi an di sekan die wi riich a Pyutiyoli.

There we found brothers, and were invited to remain with them for seven days. And so we went to Rome.|Wi fain som piipl we biliiv iina Jiizas de an dem beg wi fi tan wid dem fi sevn die. Afta dat wi lef an go a Ruom.

From there, when the brothers heard of us, they traveled as far as the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage. |Wen di breda an sista dem a Ruom ier bout wi, som a dem kom aal di wie a Apiyos Maakit, an som kom a di plies kaal Chrii In kom miit wi. Wen Paal si dem im tek aat an gi Gad tangks.

When we arrived at Rome, the centurion handed the prisoners over to the captain of the guard. But Paul was allowed to remain by himself with the soldier who guarded him.|Wen wi riich a Ruom, di govament lou Paal fi liv a wan ous im wan, nobadi neehn afi tan de wid im onggl di suoja we gyaad im.

After three days Paul called the leaders of the Jews together. When they had assembled, he said to them, “Brothers, having done nothing contrary to our people or the customs of our fathers, I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.|Chrii die afta dat, Paal sen kaal di Juu liida dem iina di ieriya fi miit wid im. Wen dem kom im se tu dem se, “Mi breda, mi neva du notn rang gens wi piipl. Mi neva se notn rang bout di wie wi faada faada dem did liv niida. Bot wi liida dem iina Jeruusilem tek mi ton prizna gi di Ruoman liida dem.

When they had examined me, they were determined to release me, because there was no charge against me deserving death.|Afta dem kwestiyan mi an fain out se mi neva du notn rang we wuda gi dem di rait fi kil mi, dem did waahn fi let mi go.

But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, not that I had any charge to bring against my nation. |Bot di Juu dem neva waahn di liida dem fi let mi go, so mi did afi tel di liida dem se mi waahn Siiza fi joj mi imself. Bot mi no av notn gens mi uona piipl.

For this reason I have asked to see you and speak with you, because I am bound with this chain for the hope of Israel.”|A dat mek mi aks unu fi miit wid mi. Matarafak, dem tek mi ton prizna an put mi iina dem chien ya siek-a di wan we di Izrel piipl dem a wiet fa an a luk fi kom.”

They said to him, “We have not received any letters from Judea concerning you, and none of the brothers that have come have reported or spoken any evil of you.|Di liida dem se, “Wi no get no leta fram Judiya bout yu, an non a di breda dem no kom fram op de kom tel wi notn bad bout yu niida.

But we think it is proper to hear from you what you think. For concerning this sect, we know that it is spoken against everywhere.”|Bot wi wuda laik fi ier wa yu tingk, kaaz wi nuo se piipl evriwe taak gens da gruup ya we yu bilang tu.”

When they had arranged a day to be with him, many came to him at his residence. From morning until evening he explained and solemnly testified of the kingdom of God to them, persuading them concerning Jesus from both the Law of Moses and the Prophets. |So dem set di taim fi miit wid im. Wen dem shuo op a im ous fi di miitn, uol iip muor a dem kom dan di fos taim. Fram maanin til iivnin, Paal taak tu dem an elp dem andastan di mesij bout Gad kindom an Jiizas. An im yuuz di Laa we Muoziz did rait dong, an wa di prafit dem did rait fi get dem fi biliiv se wa im did a tel dem bout Gad kindom a chuu.
Some believed what was said, but some did not believe.|Som a dem biliiv wa Paal se, bot som a dem mek op dem main no fi biliiv an ton dem bak pan Gad mesij.

Being in disagreement with one another, they were dismissed after Paul had said one word: “The Holy Spirit accurately spoke to our fathers through Isaiah the prophet,|So di liida dem staat aagyu mongks dem wan aneda an som a dem waak out afta di laas ting Paal se. Im did se, “Di Uoli Spirit did rait wen im did yuuz di prafit Aizaiya fi taak tu wi faada faada dem.

‘Go to this people and say:You shall certainly hear, but never understand;and you shall certainly see, but never perceive;|Im se,“ ‘Go tu dem piipl ya an se tu dem se,“Unu a-go aalwiez a lisn gud,bot unu naa go andastan wa unu ier.Unu a-go kip aan a luk aad aad,bot unu naa go si notn.”

for the heart of this people has grown dull.Their ears are hard of hearing,and they have closed their eyes,lest they should see with their eyesand hear with their earsand understand with their heartand turn, and I would heal them.’|Kaaz dem piipl ya blak dem main,brok tik iina dem iez,an lak dem yai dem,so dem kyaahn si wid dem yai dem, ar ier wid dem iez deman andastan wid dem main,an ton we fram wa rang, an mi wuda iil dem.’
“Therefore let it be known to you that the salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles. They will hear it!”
column2: “So mi waahn unu fi nuo se Gad mesij bout ou im a-go siev piipl a-go go tu di piipl dem we a no Juu. Dem wi lisn!”

column1: When he had said these words, the Jews departed and disputed greatly among themselves. |Afta im tel dem dem sopm ya, di joo dem lef an kwaril mongs dem wana neda.
Paul remained two whole years in his own rented house. He welcomed all who came to him
column2: Fi tuu uol-a ier Paal liv iina im uona ous we im rent. Im tek iin evribadi we kom tu im

column1: boldly and freely preaching the kingdom of God and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ.
column2: an priich tu dem bout Gad kindom an tiich dem bout di Laad Jiizas Krais. An im neva fried fi tiich bout di Laad Jiizas an notn neva de de fi tap im.

column1: God, who at various times and in diverse ways spoke long ago to the fathers through the prophets|Iina di uol taim die dem Gad yuus tu yuuz im prafit dem uol iip a taim, an iina aal kain-a wie fi taak tu wi faada faada dem.

has in these last days spoken to us by His Son, whom He has appointed heir of all things, and through whom He made the world. |Bot iina dem laas die ya, im yuuz im Bwai Pikni fi taak tu wi. Im pik im, an kom gi im evriting. Gad pik im tu, so Gad kuda mek di worl.

He is the brightness of His glory, the express image of Himself, and upholds all things by the word of His power. When He had by Himself purged our sins, He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high. |Wen yu luk pan Gad Bwai Pikni, yu kyan si Gad brait brait lait. An im shuo ou Gad tan, kaaz im komiin jos laik Gad. An im powaful wod mek evriting tan jos laik ou dem fi tan. So wen im don mek di wie so piipl kyan get paadn fram sin im go sidong op a evn, rait saida di wan we muo powaful dan evribadi els. An wich paat im sidong iina evn, a di tap-a-tap pozishan dat, an im get fi ruul uova evriting.
He was made so much better than the angels as He has inherited a more excellent name than they.|A so kom im get fi ton aiya dan di ienjel dem, kaaz di niem we im get aiya dan fi dem uon.

For to which of the angels did He at any time say:“You are My Son;today I have become Your Father”?Or again,“I will be a Father to Him,and He shall be a Son to Me”?|Kaaz wich wan a di ienjel dem Gad eva se dis tu, iihn,“Yu a fi mi Bwai Pikni;tide mi ton fi yu faada”?Ar wich wan a dem im eva se dis bout,“Mi a-go ton fi'im faada,an im a-go ton fi mi Bwai Pikni”?
And again, when He brings the firstborn into the world, He says:“Let all the angels of God worship Him.”|Bot wen Gad bring im fos bwai kom iina di worl, im se,

Of the angels He says:“He makes His angels spirits,and His servants a flame of fire.”|An wen im a taak bout di ienjel dem, a dis im se,“Gad mek im ienjel dem fi komiin laka briiz,an im mek dem fi komiin laka faiya we de bliez op.”

But to the Son He says:“Your throne, O God, lasts forever and ever;a scepter of righteousness is the scepter of Your kingdom.|Bot dis a wa im se bout di Bwai Pikni,“Uo Gad! Yu a-go ruul fi eva an eva!An yu a-go ruul di rait wie fi chuu.

You have loved righteousness and hated wickedness;therefore God, Your God, has anointed Youwith the oil of gladness more than Your companions.”|Yu lov wa rait, an yu iet wa no rait.A so kom mi, fi yu Gad, pik yu uova yu fren deman mek yu wel api.

And,“You, Lord, laid the foundation of the earth in the beginning,and the heavens are the works of Your hands.|Im se dis tu,“Laad, wen notn neva de bout yet, a yu mek di ort.An yu tek fi yu uona an dem an mek di skai an evriting els.

They will perish, but You remain;and they all will wear out like a garment;|Aal a dem sitn de duo, a-go mash op an don fa,bot yu — yu a-go de bout fi eva,bot di uol a dem a-go wier out laka uol kluoz.

as a cloak You will fold them up,and they will be changed.But You are the same,and Your years will not end.|Yu a-go fuol dem op laik jakit we no gud agen.So dem a-go chienj laik uol kluoz,bot yu naa chienj,yu a tan siem wie an yu naa ded niida.”

But to which of the angels did He at any time say:“Sit at My right hand,until I make Your enemiesYour footstool”?|Wich wan a di ienjel dem Gad eva se dis tu:“Sidong rait saida mi, a mi rait an, an kom ruul uova evriting.Sidong de til mi mek yu enimi dem kom ben dong infronta yu,mek yu kak op yu fut pan dem”?
Are they not all ministering spirits sent out to minister to those who will inherit salvation?|Aal a di ienjel dem, no spirit dem — spirit we Gad sen fi go sorv di piipl dem we a-go get siev? No so?
Therefore we should be more attentive to what we have heard, lest we drift away.|Siek-a dat, wi afi lisn di Gud Nyuuz we wi did ier nou muo dan wi yuus tu, so wi no chrie.

For if the word spoken by angels was true, and every sin and disobedience received a just recompense|Kaaz ef di mesij we di ienjel dem did gi, ton out chuu, an ef aal a di piipl dem we du rang, an dem we neva lisn, did get ponish laik ou dem fi get ponish

how shall we escape if we neglect such a great salvation, which was first declared by the Lord, and was confirmed to us by those who heard Him?|den a ou wi a-go get we, ef wi ton wi bak pan da impuotant mesij ya bout ou Gad a-go siev wi, an no pie it no main, iihn? A di Laad Jiizas imself did fos tel piipl bout it yu nuo. An den di piipl dem we did ier im, mek wi nuo se it go so fi chuu.

God also bore them witness with signs and wonders and diverse miracles and with gifts of the Holy Spirit distributed according to His own will.|An Gad yuuz sain an shuo se dis a chuu sopm. Som sitn we im du, piipl kyaahn biliiv dem yai di wie dem sopraiz! Plos im yuuz aal kain-a mirikl. An im aal mek piipl get wa di Uoli Spirit kom gi. Dem get it jos laik ou im did waahn it fi go. An aal a dat shuo se wa di piipl dem did se riili riili chuu.
For it was not to the angels that He has subjected the world to come, of which we are speaking.|Kaaz di worl we a-go kom — di worl wi a taak bout nou, im neehn mek ienjel kanchuol it.

But someone in a certain place testified, saying:“What is man that You are mindful of him,or the son of man that You care for him?|An sumadi, somwe iina Gad wod, did se,“Gad, wa piipl wot mek yu bizniz wid dem so?Wa mek wi, we a jos piipl, mata so moch tu yu mek yu kier bout wi, iihn?

You made him a little lower than the angels;You crowned him with glory and honor,and set him over the works of Your hands.| Fi wan likl wail yu mek man luo dong dan di ienjel dem.Yu gi im powa. Yu riez im op ai ai, laik a kroun yu put aan pan im ed.

You have put all things in subjection under his feet.”For in subjecting all things under him, He left nothing that is not subjected to him. Yet now we do not see all things subject to him.|Yu mek im av powa uova evriting.”An wen yu mek im inchaaj a evriting, dat miin se notn no de we im naa no kanchuol uova. Bot rait ya nou, wi no si se a im kanchuol evriting.

But we see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels to suffer death, crowned with glory and honor, so that He, by the grace of God, should experience death for everyone.|Wa wi si ya nou a Jiizas. Fi wan likl wail im did de luo dong dan di ienjel dem, bot nou im av powa. Nou Gad riez im op ai ai laik a wan kroun im put pan im ed. Im av powa an Gad riez im op ai ai kaaz im sofa an ded. An kaaz Gad lov wi so moch iivn duo wi no dizorv it, im mek Jiizas ded fi evribadi.

For it was fitting for Him, for whom and by whom all things exist, in bringing many sons to glory, to make the Author of their salvation perfect through suffering.|Evriting a Gad uon, an im yuuz im powa mek evriting an kip dem ou dem fi tan. So a di rait ting im du wen im mek di wan we a-go liid piipl fi get siev, sofa, an da wie de get fi im rait pozishan. Gad du dat so im kuda yuuz im fi mek uol iip a piipl kom fala im an ton Gad pikni dem.

For both He who sanctifies and those who are sanctified are all of One. For this reason He is not ashamed to call them brothers|Di tuu a dem kom fram wan fambili: di wan we mek piipl gud an kliin an di piipl dem we a ton gud an kliin. So chuu dat, Jiizas no shiem fi se dem a im breda an sista dem.

saying:“I will declare Your name to My brothers;in the midst of the congregation I will sing praise to You.”|Im se tu Gad se,“Mi wi tel mi breda an sista dem wa yu du an ou yu tan;wen dem gyada fi worship, mi wi sing im, an priez yu infronta di uol a dem.”

And again:“I will put My trust in Him.”And again:“Here am I and the children whom God has given Me.”|An im se agen se,“Mi — mi wi chos iina im.”An im se dis tu,“Si mi ya, mi de ya wid di pikni dem we Gad did gi mi.”

So then, as the children share in flesh and blood, He likewise took part in these, so that through death He might destroy him who has the power of death, that is, the devil|So den, sins dem pikni ya a piipl laik evribadi els, im did ton sumadi jos laka dem, da wie de, wen im go ded, im kuda tek we di devl powa, an mek im naa no muo powa fi kil nobadi.
and deliver those who through fear of death were throughout their lives subject to bondage. |An siek-a dat, im frii di piipl dem we komiin laik sliev fi aal a dem laif jos kaaz dem fried fi ded.
For surely He does not help the angels, but He helps the seed of Abraham. |Kaaz fi riil, a no di ienjel dem im bizniz wid so moch, bot a Iebriyam pikni pikni dem.
